title: 109_s3559
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits by adding a new section to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. This new section, titled "Fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits," outlines specific actions that constitute fraud in such circumstances. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits by adding a new section to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. This new section outlines specific fraudulent actions related to major disaster or emergency benefits, including falsifying, concealing, or making false statements in connection with disaster relief or procurement of property. In cases involving benefits related to disaster declarations or emergency procurement, individuals may face fines, imprisonment up to 30 years, or both. The circumstances under this section refer to specific fraudulent actions outlined in the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005". Individuals involved in emergency or disaster-related contracts with the United States may face fines, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both. The fraudulent actions specified in the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" include benefit transportation affecting interstate or foreign commerce and mail transportation. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" specifies that benefits related to emergency or disaster contracts with the United States must involve interstate or foreign commerce, mail transportation, or be a record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value of the United States or its agencies. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" defines benefits as any record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value provided by the United States, State, or local government. SEC. 3. INCREASED CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR WIRE, RADIO, AND TELEVISION FRAUD DURING A PRESIDENTIALLY DECLARED MAJOR DISASTER OR EMERGENCY. Amends Section 1343 of title 18, United States Code to include fraud related to benefits in connection with a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. Section 1343 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include increased criminal penalties for engaging in mail fraud during and in relation to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code to increase criminal penalties for mail fraud related to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to amend sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. The Sentencing Commission must amend sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. The Commission is also required to submit an explanation of actions taken and policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of offenses related to major disasters or emergencies and consider any circumstances that may justify exceptions. The Sentencing Commission must consider aggressive law enforcement actions to prevent offenses related to major disasters or emergencies, ensure consistency with other directives and guidelines, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, and align with the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law. The Sentencing Commission must consider making necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, including enhancements, conforming adjustments, and ensuring alignment with the purposes of sentencing within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. The Sentencing Commission must promptly issue guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of this Act, following the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987.
